questions.text: In a neonate with a leaky meningomyelocele with CSF dripping out, it should be covered with which of the following before surgery is undertaken?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The exposed meningomyelocele saccontaining neural tissue should be covered with a sterile Saline-soaked gauze. Exposed neural tissue should not be covered or wiped with any irritant, not even Povidone-Iodine.

Perinatal Care for Meningomyelocele

  • Prone or lateral position nursing
  • Cover the sac with a sterile, saline-moistened gauze
  • Prophylactic antibiotics
  • Consider a doughnut ring to prevent sac rupture in MC & MMC
  • Monitor OFC, AF & Vitals closely

questions.text: Failure of closure of anterior neuropore at what time is responsible for producing the congenital defect as shown?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

The image is showing a severe type of neural tube defect, called Anencephaly, which occurs due to failure of closure of the anterior neuropore around the 25th day, ie, 4th week.

  • Neural tube closure is typically completed by the end of the 4th week of embryonic development.
  • The anterior (cranial) neuropore closes around day 25; failure of this closure results in
  • The open neural tube leads to failure of the development of the skull vault.
  • The embryologic precursor stages of anencephaly start with acrania (absence of the skull), followed by exencephaly (cerebral tissue protruding without an overlying skull), and ultimately, the cerebral tissue degenerates because of prolonged exposure to the amniotic fluid.
  • In anencephaly, the cerebral hemispheres and cerebellum are usually absent, and only a residue of the brainstem can be identified.
  • Anencephaly is usually not compatible with life, with children being either stillborn or expiring soon after birth.
  • The posterior (caudal) neuropore closes by approximately day 27; failure to close leads to spina bifida.

questions.text: Chiari malformation is most commonly associated with which of the following congenital anomalies?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Meningomyelocele is a common association of Chiari-2 malformations.

  • Myelomeningocele is the most common neural tube defect and results from incomplete closure of the posterior neural tube, leading to protrusion of neural tissue through a defect in the vertebra.
  • Most children with a myelomeningocele also have displacement of the cerebellum and brainstem down through the foramen magnum, which is termed a Chiari II malformation.
  • Hydrocephalus in association with a type II Chiari malformation develops in at least 80% of patients with myelomeningocele due to aqueductal stenosis.
  • The classic manifestations include caudal displacement of the cerebellum, pons, and medulla and elongation of the fourth ventricle.
  • There is an associated neurological deficit, the extent of which depends on the level of the defect.
  • Club feet and dislocated hips may be present.
  • If the child has a symptomatic Chiari II malformation, surgical decompression is indicated.

Explanation of other options:

Leptomeningeal cyst (Option B): Occurs when a traumatic skull fracture in infants or children leads to herniation of arachnoid (leptomeninges) through the bone defect. It is an acquired lesion, not congenital.

Agenesis of corpus callosum (Option C): Agenesis of the corpus callosum results from defective midline prosencephalic development. This leads to a congenital absence of the corpus callosum, the major fibre tract connecting the cerebral hemispheres. Usually associated with brain abnormalities like cortical dysplasias, periventricular nodular heterotopias, and intracranial cysts.

Dandy-Walker anomaly (Option D): Dandy-­ Walker malformation consists of cystic dilation of the fourth ventricle, hypoplasia or agenesis of the cerebellar vermis, and an enlarged posterior fossa. There is upward displacement lateral venous sinuses, while in type II Chiari malformation, there is downward herniation of the hindbrain.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not a likely cause of microcephaly?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Dandy Walker typically presents with macrocephaly due to hydrocephalus, and not microcephaly.

  • Dandy-­ Walker malformation is characterised by a triad of:
    • Cystic dilation of the fourth ventricle
    • Hypoplasia or agenesis of the cerebellar vermis
    • Enlarged posterior fossa with elevation of the lateral venous sinuses and the tentorium.
  • It is associated with agenesis of corpus callosum, severe developmental delay, cerebellar ataxia and spasticity.
  • Most patients will develop hydrocephalus in infancy, and variable degrees of neurologic impairment are usually present.

Explanation of other options:

Congenital rubella (Option B): Congenital rubella syndrome can cause microcephaly if there is no aqueductal stenosis.
Rett syndrome (Option C): This syndrome is characterised as a disorder of early brain development marked by a period of developmental regression and deceleration of brain growth after a relatively normal neonatal course. It causes late-onset secondary acquired microcephaly, where head size appears normal at birth, but microcephaly becomes evident after 3 to 6 months of age.

Edward's syndrome (Option D): Edward's syndrome occurs due to Trisomy of chromosome 18, which presents with multiple congenital abnormalities, including microcephaly, prominent occiput, low-set ears, clenched fists, and cardiac defects.

questions.text: A 7-day-old neonate presents with recurrent seizures, tachycardia, and a cranial bruit audible over the anterior fontanelle. Cardiovascular examination reveals an S3 gallop. Routine blood investigations are within normal limits. MRI brain and cerebral angiography images of a neonate are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on the imaging findings?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The MRI image shows a midline saccular dilation posterior to the third ventricle, and the angiogram reveals arteriovenous shunting into a dilated midline venous structure. These are classic imaging findings of Vein of Galen malformation.

Vein Of Galen Malformation:

  • A vein of Galen malformation is an arteriovenous fistula between intracranial arteries and the embryologic median prosencephalic vein.
  • This vascular malformation is characterised by marked distension of the median prosencephalic vein and distension of downstream dural sinuses, commonly through a persistent embryologic falcine sinus.
  • The ensuing high-­ velocity arteriovenous shunting can cause venous hypertension, communicating hydrocephalus, and high-­ output cardiac failure.
  • On auscultation, a cranial bruit can be heard over the anterior fontanelle.
  • The investigation of choice is cerebral angiography, which reveals a large midline saccular dilation, confirming the diagnosis.
  • The primary treatment modality is still endovascular intervention -embolisation, rather than CSF diversion.
MRI brain showing Vein of Galen Malformation

Explanation of other options:

Arachnoid cyst (Option A): Arachnoid cysts are relatively common, benign and asymptomatic lesions occurring in association with the central nervous system. They are usually located within the subarachnoid space and contain CSF. They appear as Well-circumscribed, extra-axial masses that are isodense to CSF on CT with no enhancement identified.

Dilated ventricles (Option C): Dilated ventricles are usually seen in hydrocephalus,s where MRI shows symmetrical enlargement of the ventricular system due to abnormal CSF accumulation, without any focal saccular vascular structure, flow voids, or bruit.

Intraventricular haemorrhage (Option D): In premature infants, germinal matrix haemorrhage may rupture into the ventricular system, creating intraventricular haemorrhage. Imaging in intraventricular haemorrhage shows echogenic or hyperdense blood within the ventricles, with severe cases demonstrating associated ventricular dilatation.

questions.text: Folic acid requirement in pregnancy for prevention of neural tube defects in a lady with previous pregnancy having neural tube defect is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Folic acid supplementation decreases the incidence and recurrence of NTDs.
  • Because the neural tube closes within the first 28 days of conception, periconceptional supplementation is needed for prevention.
  • It is recommended that women without a prior history of a NTD ingest 400 μg/day of folic acid throughout their reproductive years.
  • Women with a history of a prior pregnancy complicated by an NTD or a first-degree relative with an NTD should have preconceptional counselling and should ingest 4 mg/day (4000 μg) of supplemental folic acid beginning at least 1 month before conception.
  • Use of some antiepileptic drugs (valproate, carbamazepine) during pregnancy is associated with an increased risk of NTD.
  • Women taking these medications should ingest 1-­ 5 mg of folic acid daily in the preconception period.

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant presents with delayed milestones and an increasing head circumference. Neuroimaging is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows dilation of the fourth ventricle with an enlarged posterior fossa, which, along with developmental delay and macrocephaly, suggests Dandy-Walker malformation.

  • Dandy-Walker malformation is characterised by a triad of:
    • Cystic dilation of the fourth ventricle
    • Hypoplasia or agenesis of the cerebellar vermis
    • Enlarged posterior fossa with elevation of the lateral venous sinuses and the tentorium.
  • It is associated with agenesis of corpus callosum, severe developmental delay, cerebellar ataxia and spasticity.
  • Most patients will develop hydrocephalus in infancy, and variable degrees of neurologic impairment are usually present.

Explanation of other options:

Arnold Chiari malformation (Option A): In Arnold Chiari Malformation, both cerebellar and brain stem tissue protrude into the foramen magnum, and the cerebellar vermis may be only partially complete or absent. Commonly associated with lumbosacral meningomyelocele and hydrocephalus. MRI shows downward displacement of cerebellar structures, not fourth ventricle dilation.

Cisterna magna congenita (Option B): This condition is a cause of posterior fossa CSF collection and refers to an isolated, benign enlargement of the cisterna magna, with a normal-sized cerebellum and no associated structural abnormalities.

Congenital absence of cerebellum (Option D): Cerebellar agenesis is a rare condition where the entire cerebellum is absent or rudimentary, with a normal-sized posterior fossa. Unlike Dandy-Walker malformation, the fourth ventricle is typically normal, and there is complete, not partial, cerebellar absence.

questions.text: A stillborn neonate is examined after delivery. Based on the findings shown in the image below, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Image (a) demonstrates anencephaly, and image (b) reveals a completely open spinal defect consistent with spina bifida; the presence of both suggests the diagnosis of craniorachischisis.

  • Craniorachischisis is the most severe form of neural tube defect, characterised by a combination of:
    • Anencephaly (failure of anterior neuropore closure)
    • Total spina bifida/rachischisis (failure of posterior neuropore closure)
  • It results from the failure of closure of both the anterior and posterior neuropores and is incompatible with life.

questions.text: A full-term neonate is born to a mother who did not receive folic acid supplementation during pregnancy. The baby was asymptomatic at birth, but examination revealed a midline lesion over the lower back, as shown below. Based on the clinical presentation and image findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

A neonate born to a mother who did not take folic acid is at risk for neural tube defects such as spina bifida occulta. The image shows a tuft of hair over the lumbosacral region, suggesting underlying occult spinal dysraphism.

Spina bifida occulta:

  • Occult spinal dysraphisms, often called spina bifida occulta, are a closed neural tube defect that consists of a midline defect of the vertebral bodies without protrusion of the spinal cord or meninges.
  • These are the most common types of neural tube defects.
  • Patients are usually asymptomatic and do not require any specific therapy.
  • A spine x-­ ray in simple spina bifida occulta shows a defect in closure of the posterior vertebral arches and laminae, typically involving L5 and S1.
  • However, a spine x-­ ray in cases with spinal cord involvement might show bone defects or may be normal.
  • All cases of occult spinal dysraphism are best investigated with MRI.
  • Initial screening in the neonate may include ultrasonography, but MRI is more accurate at any age.

Cutaneous markers for spina bifida occulta include

  • Tuft of hair
  • Lipoma
  • Dermal sinus
  • Hemangioma

Explanation of other options:

Anencephaly (Option A): Failure of this closure of the anterior neuropore results in anencephaly.

In anencephaly, the cerebral hemispheres and cerebellum are usually absent, and only a residue of the brainstem can be identified. Anencephaly is usually not compatible with life, with children being either stillborn or expiring soon after birth.

Meningocele (Option B): A meningocele is formed when the meninges herniate through a defect in the posterior vertebral arches or the anterior sacrum. The infant is born with a soft mass in the lumbar or sacral region through which cerebrospinal fluid may exude. The open meninges may get infected. Early repair is essential.

Tethered Cord Syndrome (Option D): Tethered cord syndrome occurs when the spinal cord is abnormally fixed within the spinal canal, preventing its normal movement during flexion and extension, leading to stretching and neurological symptoms like gait changes, bladder/bowel dysfunction, and scoliosis. It is commonly associated with occult spinal dysraphism, including lipomyelomeningocele, diastematomyelia, myelocystocele or a thickened filum terminale.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with multiple hyperpigmented brown macules on the skin, along with similar lesions in the axillary region. His IQ is normal, but a brain MRI showed basal ganglia hyperintensities on the T2-weighted image without any mass effect, as shown below. A repeat MRI done 2 years later demonstrated a disappearance of these lesions. What is the likely diagnosis?.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A child with multiple hyperpigmented brown macules suggests the presence of café-au-lait spots, and similar lesions in the axillary region indicate axillary freckling. Together, these are characteristic of Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1).

  • NF1 results from an autosomal dominant loss-of-function mutation in the NF1
  • Affected children are prone to various neurologic complications.
  • MRI in selected patients often reveals T2-weighted hyperintensities involving the optic tracts, brainstem, globus pallidus, thalamus, internal capsule, and cerebellum.
  • These lesions, known as unidentified bright objects (UBOs) or focal areas of signal abnormality (FASI), typically resolve with age, most disappearing by adulthood (around 30 years).
  • The pathological basis of UBOs remains unclear, and their relationship with cognitive, behavioural, and speech impairments in NF1 is still debated.
  • Therefore, brain MRI should be reserved for children who present with relevant clinical symptoms, rather than for routine screening.

Fig: A) café-au-lait spots;

B) Axillary freckling

Explanation of other options:

NF-1 with Optic Nerve Gliomas (Option B): Optic pathway gliomas are present in approximately 15-20% of individuals with NF1. The brain MRI findings of an optic glioma include diffuse thickening, localised enlargement, or a distinct focal mass originating from the optic nerve or chiasm.

Fig: Optic glioma. Sagittal T1-­ T1-weighted MRI scan of a patient with NF1 shows thickening of the optic nerve.

NF-1 with TIA (Option C): NF1 can be associated with cerebral aneurysms or stenosis consistent with moyamoya syndrome, which may result in neurologic sequelae like transient cerebrovascular ischemic attacks, hemiparesis, and cognitive defects. MRI in TIA may be normal or can show ischemic changes.

Tuberous Sclerosis with cortical tubers (Option D): Tuberous sclerosis presents with hypopigmented ash-leaf spots, facial angiofibromas, and periungual fibromas. MRI shows cortical/subcortical tubers and subependymal nodules, which are persistent, calcify with age, and do not resolve.

choices.text: Presence of 6 cafe-au-lait macules measuring ≥18 mm in a post-pubertal male
3 Lisch nodules confined to the iris of one eye

questions.text: Which of the following findings is not consistent with the diagnostic criteria for Neurofibromatosis type 1?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

According to NF1 criteria, a solitary non-plexiform neurofibroma does not fulfil the criterion and is not compatible with an NF1 diagnosis. The presence of two or more neurofibromas of any type or one plexiform neurofibroma is required.

Neuroffibromatosis 1:

  • NF1 has an incidence of 1 in 2,500 live births and is caused by autosomal dominant loss-­ of-­ function pathogenic variants in the NF1 gene.
  • The disease is clinically diagnosed when any two of the following manifestations are present:
    • Six or more café-­ au-­ lait macules (CALMs) >5 mm in greatest diameter in prepubertal individuals and >15 mm in greatest diameter in postpubertal individuals. (Option A ruled out)
    • Axillary or inguinal freckling consisting of multiple hyperpigmented areas 2-­ 3 mm in diameter
    • Two or more iris Lisch nodules (Option C ruled out)
    • Two or more neurofibromas or one plexiform neurofibroma.
    • A distinctive osseous lesion, such as sphenoid dysplasia, anterolateral bowing of the tibia, or pseudarthrosis of a long bone (Option D ruled out)
    • Optic pathway gliomas
    • A parent with NF1 whose diagnosis was based on the aforementioned criteria.
    • A pathogenic NF1 gene variant.

Fig: A) Café-au-lait macules; B) Axillary Freckling; C) Neurofibromas; D) Plexiform Neuroma; E) Lisch Nodules

questions.text: A 12-year-old male is brought to the pediatric OPD with complaints of a rough, raised, scaly, yellow-white lesion on the lower back, as shown below. The mother reports that the child has intellectual disability and experienced an episode of abnormal body movements lasting about 5 minutes last night. The MRI brain taken is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of a rough, raised, scaly, yellow-white lesion on the lower back, consistent with a Shagreen patch and MRI shows cortical tubers, which, along with intellectual disability and a recent seizure episode, are highly suggestive of tuberous sclerosis.

Tuberous sclerosis:

  • Tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC) is a multisystem disease characterised by an autosomal dominant mode of inheritance.
  • The hallmark of TSC is the involvement of the CNS. The characteristic brain lesion is a cortical tuber.
  • Brain MRI is the best way of identifying cortical tubers, which can form before birth.
  • More than 90% of patients show the typical hypomelanotic macules that have been likened to an ash leaf on the trunk and extremities.
  • A shagreen patch is also characteristic of TSC and consists of a roughened, raised lesion with an orange-­ peel consistency located primarily in the lumbosacral region.
  • Forehead fibrous plaques usually occur on one side of the forehead. They are characteristically raised, yellow-­ brown or flesh-­ colored, and soft to hard in consistency.
  • The most common neurologic manifestations of TSC are epilepsy, intellectual disability, and autism spectrum disorder.
  • Definite TSC is diagnosed when at least two major or one major plus two minor features are present. In addition, carrying a pathogenic variant in TSC1 or TSC2 is sufficient for the diagnosis of TSC.

Explanation of other options:

Sturge-Weber Syndrome (Option A): This is a sporadic disorder characterised by a facial nevus or port wine stain in the distribution of the first branch of the trigeminal nerve, along with an ipsilateral railroad pattern of intracranial calcification and glaucoma. The major manifestations are contralateral hemiplegia and intractable focal seizures, which may lead to intellectual disability.

Von Hippel-Lindau Syndrome (Option B): This is an autosomal dominant disorder characterised by cerebellar and retinal hemangioblastomas, spinal cord angiomas, and cystic tumours of the kidneys and pancreas. Cerebellar signs and raised intracranial tension are the usual manifestations.

Neurofibromatosis-1 (Option C): Hallmark features of NF-1 include café-au-lait spots, axillary freckling, neurofibromas, Lisch nodules, and optic pathway gliomas. Further brain imaging shows unidentified bright objects and not cortical tubers.

questions.text: A 1-year-old girl with developmental delay is brought for evaluation. Her mother states that she can sit but cannot stand even with support, does not speak single words, and does not point to objects. She was born full-term without perinatal complications. On examination, a detailed neurologic and skin assessment is performed. Which of the following cutaneous findings is most characteristic of tuberous sclerosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hypopigmented macules are a skin finding consistent with tuberous sclerosis.

Skin lesions in tuberous sclerosis:

  • The most common lesion is hypopigmented macules, also known as ash-leaf spots, which are usually elliptic in shape.
  • Facial angiofibromas: Develop between 4 and 6 years of age; they appear as tiny red nodules over the nose and cheeks and are sometimes confused with acne. Later, they enlarge, coalesce, and assume a fleshy appearance.
  • Shagreen patch: Roughened, raised lesion with an orange-­ peel consistency located primarily in the lumbosacral region
  • Forehead fibrous plaques usually occur on one side of the forehead. They are characteristically raised, yellow-­ brown or flesh-­ colored, and soft to hard in consistency.
  • Forehead plaques are histologically similar to facial angiofibromas, though the former can appear at any point.
  • Ungual fibromas: During adolescence or later, small fibromas or nodules of skin may form around fingernails or toenails.

Fig: Dermatologic manifestations of tuberous sclerosis. A) Hypomelanotic macules; B) Facial angiofibromas; C) Shagreen patch

Explanation of other options:

Axillary freckling (Option A), Cafe-au-lait macules (Option B): Both are hallmark cutaneous manifestations of neurofibromatosis. Cafe-au-lait macules are present in almost 100% of patients and are present at birth but increase in size, number, and pigmentation, especially during the first few years of life. Axillary or inguinal freckling consisting of multiple hyperpigmented areas 2-­ 3 mm in diameter.

Port wine stain (Option D): Port-wine stains, caused by capillary malformations, are typically seen in neurocutaneous disorders such as Sturge-Weber syndrome.

questions.text: A child presents with multiple small nodular swellings over the body. On axillary examination, there is hyperpigmentation as shown in the image. There is a positive family history of similar lesions. Which of the following tumours is the child most likely to develop?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows café-au-lait spots and axillary freckling, while the nodular swellings are suggestive of neurofibromas. Together, these features indicate a diagnosis of neurofibromatosis type 1, in which optic glioma is the most common tumour.

  • Optic pathway gliomas are present in approximately 15-20% of individuals with NF1.
  • However, only ∼30% of these are clinically symptomatic and require tumor-­ directed therapy.
  • Because of visual acuity compromise, it is recommended that all children with NF1 undergo at least annual ophthalmologic examinations, or more frequent ones if there is a concern.
  • The most common time to develop symptoms is between the ages of 2 and 6 years; they manifest as a change in visual acuity, a change in the visual fields, or pallor of the optic nerve.
  • Extension into the hypothalamus can lead to precocious puberty.
  • The brain MRI findings of an optic glioma include diffuse thickening, localised enlargement, or a distinct focal mass originating from the optic nerve or chiasm.

Other tumours associated with NF-1:

  • Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumours are in the family of aggressive sarcomas and occur either de novo or as the result of malignant degeneration of an existing plexiform neurofibroma.
  • Additionally, the incidence of pheochromocytoma, rhabdomyosarcoma, leukaemia, and Wilms tumour is higher than in the general population.
  • However, the most common tumour associated with NF-1 is optic gliomas.
  • Patients with NF1 are at risk for hypertension, which may be present in isolation or result from renal vascular stenosis or a pheochromocytoma.

questions.text: Which of the following is the hallmark feature of Neurofibromatosis type 2?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Bilateral vestibular schwannomas are the hallmark of NF-2, while all other findings mentioned are seen in NF-1.

  • Neurofibromatosis type 2 is less common than NF1 and is caused by mutations in the NF2 gene located on chromosome 1, which encodes the Merlin (schwannomin) protein.
  • Neurofibromatosis type 2 is an autosomal dominant disorder characterised by the occurrence of vestibular schwannomas (VSs), schwannomas of other cranial, spinal and cutaneous nerves, and other central nervous system.
  • The hallmark feature is the presence of bilateral vestibular schwannomas.
  • Individuals with NF2 may present with tinnitus, hearing loss, facial weakness, headache, and gait instability due to vestibular schwannoma.
  • Workup for NF-2 should include ophthalmologic evaluation for assessing fubcapsular or cortical cataracts, along with MRI of the brain and spine, and audiology evaluation.
  • These are all important components of ongoing surveillance and management, and the goal is to preserve hearing.

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child is being evaluated for evaluation of a seizure disorder. Clinical examination reveals a well-demarcated, flat reddish-purple vascular lesion distributed along the ophthalmic and maxillary branches of the trigeminal nerve, as shown below. The mother reports that the lesion has been present since birth without any change in morphology. Ophthalmologic assessment shows raised intraocular pressure in the ipsilateral eye. Based on the findings, what is the most likely possibility?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

The image shows a port-wine birthmark involving both the ophthalmic (V1) and maxillary (V2) dermatomes of the trigeminal nerve. The presence of this congenital vascular malformation, along with raised intraocular pressure suggestive of glaucoma, is are hallmark feature of Sturge-Weber syndrome.

  • Sturge-­ Weber syndrome (SWS) is a segmental vascular neurocutaneous disorder with a constellation of symptoms and signs characterised by a triad of
    • Facial port wine stain (unilateral; V1 and V2 distribution)
    • Ipsilateral glaucoma
    • Ipsilateral leptomeningeal angiomas
  • Usually caused by a pathologic somatic single-­ nucleotide variant in the GNAQ gene.
  • The port-wine tends to be unilateral and ipsilateral to the brain involvement.
  • Buphthalmos and glaucoma of the ipsilateral eye are common complications.
  • Low flow of the leptomeningeal capillary malformation appears to result in a chronic hypoxic state, leading to cortical atrophy and calcifications.
  • Patients present with seizures, hemiparesis, stroke-like episodes, headaches, and developmental delay.

Diagnosis:

  • Brain MRI with contrast is the imaging modality of choice for demonstrating the extension of pial capillary malformation in SWS and leptomeningeal enhancement.
  • Calcifications can be seen best with a head CT: a radial pattern of intracranial calcification is a hallmark finding.

Fig: CT scan of a patient with Sturge-­ Weber syndrome showing unilateral calcification and underlying atrophy of a cerebral hemisphere.

Explanation of other options:

Infantile hemangioma (Option B): IHs are proliferative benign vascular tumours of vascular endothelium that may be present at birth or, more commonly, may become apparent in the first or second week of life, predictably enlarge, and then spontaneously involute. The lesions are cystic, firm, or compressible, and the overlying skin may appear normal in colour or may have a bluish hue.

Congenital hemangioma (Option C): Congenital hemangiomas are benign vascular tumours that are present typically at birth. They are most often red or blue hued with telangiectasia and may have a ring of pallor. They do not undergo further growth after delivery.

Proteus syndrome (Option D): Proteus syndrome is a rare disorder of cellular growth regulation, involving both ectodermal and mesodermal tissues, due to cellular mosaicism. While port-wine stains may be seen, they are typically accompanied by other hallmark features, including Hemimegalencephaly, asymmetric overgrowth of the extremities, verrucous epidermal nevi, bony hypertrophy, and soft tissue overgrowth.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presents with slowly enlarging, firm, non-tender, non-pulsatile masses on the left side of her neck. On examination, she has multiple brown flat skin lesions on the trunk and bilateral axillary freckles. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis of the neck masses?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of brown flat skin lesions (café-au-lait spots) along with axillary freckling is are characteristic feature of Neurofibromatosis Type 1, strongly suggesting that the neck masses represent plexiform neurofibromas.

  • Neurofibromas are the most common peripheral nerve sheath tumours.
  • These lesions appear as soft, skin-coloured papules or small subcutaneous nodules. They can be localised, diffuse, and plexiform.
  • Neurofibromas are most visible on the skin, but they may occur on any peripheral nerve in the body, including along peripheral nerves and blood vessels and within viscera, including the gastrointestinal tract.
  • These lesions appear characteristically during adolescence or pregnancy, suggesting a hormonal influence.
  • They are usually small, rubbery lesions with a slight purplish discolouration of the overlying skin.
  • Plexiform neurofibromas are typically congenital and result from diffuse thickening of nerve trunks and surrounding soft tissues.
  • The skin overlying a plexiform neurofibroma may be coarse and associated with hyperpigmentation.
  • Plexiform neurofibromas may produce overgrowth of an extremity and a deformity of the corresponding bone.
  • The presence of two or more neurofibromas of any type or one plexiform neurofibroma is one of the criteria for NF-1.

Chemodectoma (Option A): Refers to carotid body tumours, which are painless, round lateral neck masses, located along the anterior border of the upper one-third of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. They usually present as pulsatile neck masses with a possible bruit on auscultation. They are not associated with NF1.

Lipoma (Option B): Lipomas are benign tumours of fat tissue and usually present as soft, mobile, painless swellings under the skin. They are not associated with café-au-lait spots or axillary freckling.

Cystic Hygroma (Option C): Cystic hygromas are soft, fluctuant, and transilluminant swellings, often in the posterior triangle of the neck. They typically appear in infancy, not adolescence, and are not associated with NF1 or pigmented skin lesions.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with multiple flat pigmented skin lesions and freckling in the axillae. Imaging reveals an optic pathway mass. Considering the likely underlying condition, which of the following is not a known complication?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cataracts are a recognised feature of NF2, not NF1, where they commonly present as posterior subcapsular opacities.

Complications in NF-1:

  • One of the most common complications is a learning disability affecting more than half of individuals with NF1. (Option A ruled out)
  • Seizures are observed in approximately 8% of NF1 patients.
  • The cerebral vessels may develop aneurysms or stenosis consistent with moyamoya syndrome.
  • Neurologic sequelae of these vascular abnormalities include transient cerebrovascular ischemic attacks, hemiparesis, and cognitive defects.
  • Precocious puberty may become evident in the presence or absence of lesions of the optic pathway tumours. (Option C ruled out)
  • Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumours are in the family of aggressive sarcomas and occur either de novo or as the result of malignant degeneration of an existing plexiform neurofibroma. The lifetime risk is 8-13%.
  • Additionally, the incidence of pheochromocytoma, rhabdomyosarcoma, leukaemia, and Wilms tumour is higher than in the general population.
  • Scoliosis is a common complication found in approximately 10% of patients. (Option D ruled out)
  • Patients with NF1 are at risk for hypertension, which may be present in isolation or result from renal vascular stenosis or a pheochromocytoma.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents with progressive difficulty in walking and climbing stairs, along with poor head control, over the past few months. His maternal uncle had similar symptoms in early childhood and died in his late twenties. On examination, there is calf muscle enlargement as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Duchenne muscular dystrophy:

  • Duchenne muscular dystrophy is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by a mutation in the dystrophin gene.
  • It is the most common inherited neuromuscular disorder.
  • Children are not usually symptomatic at birth and usually achieve their baby milestones.

Clinical features:

  • In the first year of life, children with DMD are typically asymptomatic or show only subtle signs, making early diagnosis rare.
  • Clinical manifestations usually become apparent between 2 and 5 years of age.
  • By 3-4 years, gait disturbances emerge, including a waddling gait (Trendelenburg gait) due to hip muscle weakness, frequent falls, toe-walking, and difficulty running or climbing stairs.
  • Postural changes develop over time, beginning with mild lumbar lordosis that worsens with age, followed by kyphoscoliosis.
  • Mild intellectual impairment may occur due to the absence of dystrophin isoforms Dp140 and Dp71, which are also expressed in the brain.
  • Cardiac complications, particularly cardiomyopathy, usually manifest after muscle weakness and may include tachyarrhythmias, congestive cardiac failure (CCF), and myocardial fibrosis.

Signs of DMD:

  • Gower's sign: Due to proximal muscle weakness, these patients need to use their hands to push from the floor and then their thighs to stand.
  • Calf enlargement or pseudohypertrophy: Hypertrophied appearance due to deposition of fat and connective tissue
  • Valley sign: It is a depression seen B/L from the back between fibres in the deltoid, infraspinatus.
  • Tongue hypertrophy
  • Deep tendon reflexes: The knee jerk reflex becomes weak and is typically lost by 6 years of age. In contrast, the ankle jerk reflex remains preserved initially but is eventually lost once contractures develop.

Fig: A) Gower sign; B) Pseudohypotrophic calf; C) Valley sign

Explanation of other options: 

Spinal muscular atrophy type 2 (Option B): Also known as Dubowitz disease, this condition has an onset between 6 and 18 months and is characterised by proximal muscle weakness, tremors, and kyphoscoliosis.

Juvenile dermatomyositis (Option C): It is the most common inflammatory myositis in children, presenting with proximal muscle weakness but has the hallmark skin findings of a heliotrope rash and Gottron's papules.

Type 1 myotonic dystrophy (Option D): Myotonic dystrophy is characterised by abnormal facies, including an inverted V-shaped upper lip and a sad facial appearance while trying to talk or smile. Muscle weakness is distal more than proximal, often involving the intrinsic muscles of the hands and feet.

choices.text: Serum creatine kinase levels are raised during the asymptomatic period.
It follows an X-linked recessive pattern of inheritance
Ataluren is FDA-approved for the treatment of Duchenne muscular dystrophy

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Duchenne muscular dystrophy is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Ataluren is not FDA-approved for the treatment of Duchenne muscular dystrophy. It acts by promoting read-through of premature stop codons, benefiting approximately 13-15% of patients.

Duchenne's muscular dystrophy:

  • An X-linked recessive muscular dystrophy due to a mutation in the gene coding for the dystrophin protein in the muscle sarcolemma. (Option B ruled out)
  • A child with Duchenne muscular dystrophy grows normally till 18 months to 2 years of age and then starts to develop progressive myopathy, initially manifesting as frequent falls. The child becomes bedridden by 12 years of age, and death occurs by 15 years of age. (Option D ruled out)
  • Waddling gait, positive Gower sign, and pseudohypertrophy of calf muscles are classical findings.

Investigations:

  • Screening test - Serum creatine kinase levels:
    • Serum creatine kinase levels are typically elevated even during the asymptomatic period in Duchenne muscular dystrophy, often reaching 10-100 times the normal range. (Option A ruled out)
    • As the disease progresses and significant muscle mass is lost (usually after age 12), CK levels gradually decline and may return to near-normal values in the late terminal stages since most muscle mass has atrophied.
  • Investigation of choice: Mutation analysis
    • PCR and the more sensitive multiplex ligation-dependent probe amplification (MLPA) are used for the detection of mutations.
  • Muscle biopsy: Gold standard for diagnosis.
    • Histopathology typically shows muscle fibre necrosis with replacement by fibrofatty tissue.
    • The preferred biopsy sites are the vastus lateralis or gastrocnemius muscles.
  • Immunohistochemistry: Absence of dystrophin (1,2,3) staining is seen in Duchenne dystrophy;

Treatment:

Steroid therapy:

  • Glucoocorticoids slow disease progression, reduce muscle necrosis/apoptosis, and increase survival by 2-3 years.
  • Recommended doses are prednisone 0.75 mg/kg/day or deflazacort 0.9 mg/kg/day.

Supportive measures:

  • Cardiac management: For cardiomyopathy and congestive cardiac failure, ACE inhibitors or ARBs are indicated.
  • Respiratory support: BiPAP for ventilator dependence, chest physiotherapy.
  • Orthopaedic care: Braces or surgery for scoliosis.

Newer agents:

  • Exon-skipping therapy (Antisense oligonucleotide therapy):
    • FDA-approved: Eteplirsen for exon 51 skipping - applicable to ~13% of DMD cases (mutations in exons 49-51).
    • Golodirsen and viltolarsen are additional antisense oligonucleotides that are approved for pathogenic variants in exon 53
    • Ataluren: Promotes read-through of premature stop codons in nonsense mutations, but is not yet FDA-approved.
  • Elevidys, an FDA-approved recombinant gene therapy, delivers a shortened (138kDa vs 427kDa) dystrophin protein that is expressed in muscle in children 4-5 years old after a single intravenous dose.

choices.text: Without assisted ventilation, the median age of death is 12 years
The child will likely be able to sit but not walk
Tracheostomy is the only option for survival
Cough is impaired, and use of a mechanical airway clearance device is recommended

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant presents with choking during feeds, generalised hypotonia, and visible tongue fasciculations. On physical exam, the infant appears floppy with poor head control and a weak cry. What is the most appropriate advice to give the parents at this stage?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The early age of onset, along with choking, tongue fasciculations, and a profoundly hypotonic (floppy) presentation, strongly supports a diagnosis of spinal muscular atrophy (SMA) type I.
  • In SMA type I, respiratory muscle weakness impairs cough, making infants prone to respiratory infections.
  • The use of a cough assist device, like a mechanical in-exsufflator, will help to clear secretions.

Cardinal features of SMA type I:

  • Onset before the age of 6 months
  • Severe hypotonia
  • Symmetric generalised muscle weakness affecting the lower limbs more than the upper limbs, proximal more than distal
  • Frog-­ leg posture
  • Absence of deep tendon reflexes
  • Tongue fasciculations
  • SMA is in the differential diagnosis list of floppy infant syndrome. Infants lie flaccid with little movement, unable to overcome gravity, and lack head control.
  • Infants with SMA type I develop respiratory failure within the first 2 years of life, and without respiratory and nutritional support, they usually do not survive beyond their second birthday.

Explanation of other options:

Without assisted ventilation, the median age of death is at 12 years (Option A): The median age of death without assisted ventilation is around 12 years in SMA type II, not SMA type I.

In SMA type I, without respiratory support, most infants die before 2 years of age due to respiratory failure.

The child will likely be able to sit but not walk (Option B): This is a typical motor pattern in SMA type II, where children can sit independently but never achieve walking.

However, in SMA type I, affected infants never achieve independent sitting and often have very poor motor development from the beginning.

Tracheostomy is the only option for survival (Option C): Tracheostomy may be considered in cases where non-invasive methods are insufficient or if long-term continuous ventilation is required, but it is not the initial or only option for respiratory support in SMA Type I.

Key Takeaways:

questions.text: The image below shows a child with muscular dystrophy, facial weakness, and a characteristic facies. Based on the findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows a child with an elongated face and facial weakness, which, along with a history of muscular dystrophy, and facial weakness suggests myotonic dystrophy.

Myotonic dystrophy:

  • Also called dystrophic myotonia, myotonic dystrophy is the second most common muscular dystrophy in children and the most common muscular dystrophy in individuals over 20 years of age.
  • Myotonic dystrophy, inherited as an autosomal dominant trait, is caused by a CTG trinucleotide repeat expansion on chromosome 19.

Clinical features:

Abnormal facies:

  • The facial appearance is characteristic, consisting of an inverted-­ V-shaped upper lip, thin cheeks, and scalloped, concave temporalis muscles.
  • The head may be narrow, and the palate is high and arched.

Muscle weakness:

  • In myotonic dystrophy type 1 (DM1), muscle weakness is typically distal > proximal, affecting the intrinsic muscles of the hands and feet.
  • In contrast, myotonic dystrophy type 2 (DM2) presents with proximal > distal muscle weakness.
  • The speech is often articulated poorly and slurred because of the involvement of the muscles of the face, tongue, and pharynx.

Myotonia:

  • Does not occur in infancy and is usually not clinically or even electromyographically evident until about age 5 years.
  • During physical examination, myotonia may be demonstrated by the grip myotonia test -the patient is asked to make tight fists and then to quickly open the hands.

Other System involvement:

Explanation of other options:

Duchenne muscular dystrophy (Option A): An X-linked recessive muscular dystrophy due to a mutation in the gene coding for the dystrophin protein in the muscle sarcolemma. Waddling gait, positive Gower sign and calf muscle pseudohypertrophy are classical findings seen in Duchenne muscular dystrophy.
Becker's muscular dystrophy (Option B): Becker muscular dystrophy (BMD) is an allelic variant of Duchenne muscular dystrophy, with a similar clinical presentation but a later onset of muscle weakness compared to Duchenne.
Emery-Driefuss syndrome (Option D): Emery-Dreifuss muscular dystrophy is caused by defects in nuclear envelope proteins and presents with early contractures, muscle weakness with scapulohumeral-peroneal distribution, but no facial involvement, no myotonia, and normal intelligence.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is specifically approved for the treatment of Spinal Muscular Atrophy in pediatric patients?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Nusinersen, also called Spinraza, is a drug approved for use in patients with spinal muscular atrophy (SMA).

Drugs used in the management of spinal muscular atrophy:

The prognosis, especially for SMA type I, has been improved due to the use of genetically based treatments with three drugs: Nusinersen, Onasemnogene, and Risdiplam.

Nusinersen:

  • SMN-­ antisense oligonucleotide (ASO), nusinersen, administered intrathecally, is approved by the FDA and by the European Medicines Agency for all types of SMA patients.
  • It modifies the splicing of SMN2 by inducing an increase in exon 7 retention in SMN2 pre-­ mRNA, which finally allows a protein product similar to SMN1.

Risdipalm:

  • Risdiplam is an orally administered small molecule drug that modifies SMN2 pre-­ mRNA splicing and has been approved by the FDA for the treatment of patients with SMA who are 2 months of age or older.
  • Risdiplam promotes the inclusion of exon 7, thereby increasing the expression of full-­ length SMN2 mRNA and functional SMN protein.

Onasemnogene:

  • Onasemnogene abeparvovec is a single-­ dose intravenously administered SMN gene replacement therapy (GRT) to replace SMN1 using an adrenal AAV-9 vector.
  • It has an FDA license for use up to 2 years of age.

Types of SMA:

Explanation of other options:

Eteplirsen (Option B): Eteplirsen is an FDA-approved antisense oligonucleotide therapy that induces exon 51 skipping and is effective management of Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) patients.
Pyridostigmine (Option C): A peripheral acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used in the treatment of Myasthenia gravis to help improve muscle weakness, as it acts by increasing synaptic acetylcholine in autonomic ganglia and at peripheral muscarinic receptors, thus helping in the improvement of muscle weakness.

Riluzole (Option D): Riluzole inhibits glutamate release and is known to have neuroprotective effects, slowing disease progression in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.

questions.text: Which of the following neuromuscular disorders is caused by an underlying trinucleotide repeat expansion mutation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Myotonic dystrophy occurs due to >80 CTG trinucleotide repeats in the DMPK gene on chromosome 19q.

Myotonic muscular dystrophy:

  • Inherited as an autosomal dominant trait.
  • Classic myotonic dystrophy (type 1) (DM1, or Steinert disease) is caused by a CTG trinucleotide expansion on chromosome 19q13.3 in the 3′ untranslated region of DMPK, the gene that encodes a serine-threonine protein kinase.
  • Type 2 (DM2) is associated with an unstable CCTG tetranucleotide repeat expansion on chromosome 3q21 of an intron of the zinc finger 9 protein gene.

Clinical features:

  • Myotonic dystrophy is an example of a genetic defect causing dysfunction in multiple organ systems.
  • Children with myotonic dystrophy have dysmorphic facies characterised by inverted V-shaped lips, thin cheeks, elongated face and high arched palates.
  • The muscular atrophy and weakness in myotonic dystrophy are slowly progressive throughout childhood and adolescence and continue into adulthood.
  • Myotonia in this condition does not occur in infancy and is usually not clinically or even electromyographically evident until about age 5 years.

Diagnosis:

  • Screening test: EMG
    • EMG shows amyopathic pattern and myotonia ('revving engine' sound).
  • Investigation of choice: Genetic testing

Treatment

  • Supportive: Myotonia improves with exercise (warm-up phenomenon)
  • Drugs- carbamazepine, phenytoin and mexiletine have been used for treatment, with variable results.

Explanation of other options:

Duchenne muscular dystrophy (Option A): Duchenne muscular dystrophy is the most common inherited neuromuscular disorder with an X-linked inheritance pattern. DMD is caused by frameshift or point mutations in the dystrophin gene, leading to an absence of functional dystrophin protein.
Becker's muscular dystrophy (Option B): BMD is also due to mutations in the dystrophin gene, but the mutations are typically in-frame, resulting in a partially functional dystrophin protein. Spinal muscular dystrophy (Option D): It is a clinically heterogeneous, panethnic disorder caused by a homozygous deletion in the survival motor neuron 1 (SMN1) gene on chromosome 5q13.

choices.text: Early diagnosis and therapy show an excellent prognosis

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with a history of frequent falls, difficulty walking. He also struggles to get up from a sitting position. A muscle biopsy was performed, and the findings are shown in the image provided. Based on the clinical features and biopsy, which of the following statements is true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Muscle biopsy reveals dystrophic changes with increased connective tissue, and when correlated with the clinical picture of a 5-year-old boy exhibiting frequent falls, difficulty walking, and difficulty getting up from sitting position (Gower's sign), the findings are strongly indicative of Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD).
  • Death in males with DMD occurs in the late teens to 20s.
  • The causes of death are respiratory failure during sleep, intractable heart failure, pneumonia, or, occasionally, aspiration and airway obstruction.
  • In the recent decade, with the application of standards of care, survival has been prolonged into the 30s in many patients.

Hallmark findings in Duchenne muscular dystrophy:

  • Calf muscle pseudohypertrophy
  • Waddling gait (Trendelenburg gait)
  • Positive Gowers sign: Indicates proximal muscle weakness affecting the hip girdle, which appears between 3-5 years of age
  • Common presentations in toddlers include delayed walking, frequent falling, toe walking, trouble running or walking upstairs, developmental delay, and, less often, malignant hyperthermia after anaesthesia.
  • The muscle biopsy is diagnostic and shows characteristic changes. Myopathic changes include endomysial connective tissue proliferation, scattered degenerating and regenerating myofibers.

Explanation of other options:

Shows mitochondrial inheritance (Option A), Precipitated by a viral infection (Option B): Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy is an X-linked recessive genetic disorder, hence does not follow mitochondrially inheritance and is not triggered by viral infections. It results from dystrophin gene mutations, leading to progressive muscle degeneration independent of infectious causes.

Early diagnosis and therapy show an excellent prognosis (Option D): Early diagnosis and treatment with corticosteroids and supportive therapies can only slow the progression of the disease and improve quality of life; they do not cure the disease. Disease is progressive and ultimately fatal, though life expectancy is improving with newer therapies.

questions.text: The following sign is positive in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given image depicts the Gower Sign.
  • Positive Gower signs indicate proximal muscle weakness and thus the child, when he gets up from lying down or squatting position, the child climbs upon his own body.
  • Gower Sign was originally described in DMD, but can also occur in other conditions where proximal muscle weakness affects the hip girdle muscles bilaterally.
  • Conditions showing positive Gower sign:
    • Duchenne's muscular dystrophy
    • Becker muscular dystrophy
    • Spinal muscular atrophy
    • Pompe's disease
    • Juvenile dermatomyositis

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with progressive difficulty in lifting his schoolbag and walking long distances. His academic performance is normal, and he continues to play video games or the piano. Notably, his maternal uncle became wheelchair-bound at the age of 38. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The preservation of distal muscle strength and manual dexterity, combined with symptom onset at 12 years and a family history of a wheelchair-bound maternal uncle by age 38, strongly supports the diagnosis of Becker muscular dystrophy.

Becker's muscular dystrophy:

  • Becker muscular dystrophy (BMD) is caused by mutations in the dystrophin gene located at the Xp21 locus-the same gene implicated in Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD).
  • However, BMD presents with a milder phenotype and slower progression compared to DMD due to partial preservation of functional dystrophin.
  • DMD has an onset before 5 to 7 years of age, while in BMD, the onset is often after 5 years or 7 years of age, and most boys remain ambulatory into adulthood.
  • Calf pseudohypertrophy, cardiomyopathy, and elevated serum levels of CK are similar to those of patients with DMD.
  • Cramps on exercise and myoglobinuria may be the initial presenting features.
  • Given the increased level of activity in BMD patients, the cardiac manifestations, including tachycardia, shortness of breath, or fatigue, may be evident earlier in patients with BMD and even in the setting of independent ambulation.
  • Learning disabilities are less common.
  • The onset of weakness is later in BMD than in DMD.
  • The lifespan in patients with BMD is typically into the 40s and 50s, with cardiac complications as well as pulmonary complications frequently leading to morbidity.

Explanation of other options:

Cerebral palsy (Option A): Cerebral palsy is a non-progressive motor disorder that presents in infancy or early childhood due to perinatal brain injury. It does not worsen with age, and the normal early development in this child makes this diagnosis unlikely.

Duchenne muscular dystrophy (Option B): DMD typically presents before 5 years of age with rapidly progressive proximal muscle weakness and often cognitive impairment.

Myasthenia gravis (Option C): Myasthenia gravis is a chronic autoimmune disease of the postsynaptic end plate leading to abnormal neuromuscular transmission or blockade, characterised clinically by rapid fatigability of striated muscle, particularly extraocular and palpebral muscles and those of swallowing.

questions.text: Which of the following drug-condition pairs is incorrectly matched?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Eteplirsen is an FDA-approved drug used for the management of Duchenne muscular dystrophy.

  • Eteplirsen (Exondys 51) is an FDA-approved antisense oligonucleotide therapy designed for patients with Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD).
  • It works via exon-skipping, targeting specific mutations to partially restore dystrophin production.
  • Riluzole and Edaravone are the FDA-approved drugs used in the treatment of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.

Explanation of other options:

Nusinersen- Spinal muscular dystrophy (Option B): Nusinersen is used intrathecally in Spinal Muscular Atrophy and acts by partially activating the SMN-2 gene.

ACTH- West Syndrome (Option C): High-dose ACTH is the first-line therapy in patients with West Syndrome.

Everolimus- Tuberous Sclerosis (Option D): Everolimus is an mTOR inhibitor, useful in Subependymal Giant Cell Astrocytomas (SEGAs), which are not amenable to surgery.
